contents.title: Introduction
contents.description: What to expect from Alberta Hiking Resources.

children.value:
We pulled together a bunch of useful goodies for anyone hiking or scrambling in the Canadian Rockies üèîÔ∏èüíö
Whether you‚Äôre brand new or just looking for a few pro tips, this is your one-stop forest-friendly info hub üçÉüìö

Sami ‚Äî the original creator of this site ‚Äî is full of hiking stoke but not quite full of all the knowledge in the Rockies üòÖüèîÔ∏è
This site isn‚Äôt meant to be a one-hiker show‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs an open trailhead for a shared effort to make info better, richer, and more helpful for everyone üöÄüìö
You‚Äôre more than welcome to contribute if any of this sounds like you:
üåê You know of great hiking groups we should highlight, or can help flesh out info on the ones already listed üìù‚ú®
ü•æ You‚Äôre a hike organizer and want to share your vibe, style, and what folks should expect on your adventures üéíüí¨
üîß You‚Äôve got trail wisdom to drop ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs safety tips, gear recs, or ‚ÄúI learned this the hard way‚Äù kind of knowledge üß†‚öôÔ∏è

Whether it‚Äôs a quick fix, a full section, or just a friendly pointer to better info ‚Äî every little bit helps ü´∂üå≤

children.value: If you would like to contribute some content to this site, please
For the more tech literate folks, you can directly open a pull request on the
All content is published under the
If you are looking to join hiking events and meet hiking partners
If you are looking for pictures and ideas
If you are looking for information on specific trails, conditions, advice, etc
The following Facebook groups are useful to find hiking/scrambling, and even climbing partners.
These hiking meetup groups are grassroots communities where events are organized organically by members rather than through any formal leadership.
There‚Äôs no central organizer or hierarchy‚Äîjust like-minded hikers coming together to share adventures, suggest outings, and connect over a shared love of the outdoors.
If you‚Äôre looking for a flexible, community-driven way to meet hiking partners, these groups are a great place to start.
: Also dedicated to finding hiking/scrambling partners.
: Not dedicated to finding hiking/scrambling partners, but the community is tight-knit and people use the group to coordinate activities.
The two groups have very similar goals and rules.
Find Hiking Groups/Partners, Alberta has more members and is a bit more active.

Alberta Hikers Together encourages posting specific hiking events (come up with a suggestion you'd like to hike, and a meeting time), whereas Find Hiking Groups/Partners, Alberta has a lot of posts about people looking for hiking buddies without specific hikes in mind.
Alberta Hikers Together is a public group, so when cross posting in different groups, it's easier to post first in Alberta Hikers Together, and then share to the other groups.
Alberta Hikers & Climbers caters to those with an intermediate to advanced skill level in either hiking or climbing.

The Alberta Hikers & Climbers community is more tight-knit, and not just focused on finding hiking partners. People ask and post about trail conditions, avalanche and crevasse rescue courses,
scrambling routes, indoor climbing events, etc.

Alberta Hikers & Climbers is a place where you interact with people first (share tips, ask information, etc) to build connections, and then find hiking/scrambling/climbing partners as a result of the interaction.
The Alpine Club of Canada has

in Calgary and Canmore that organize events.
You need to purchase a
to access their event calendar and participate.
I am not familiar with these

, but I am mentioning them given how popular they are.
If anyone participating or administrating these groups is willing to add a bit more background information, please reach out.

groups generally have a more formal leadership,
so they are a great place to start for poeple looking for a more structured hiking environment.

: Even though advertised as "slow and steady", the actual speed depends on each organizer. Each organizer vets the participants and
in some cases, even have a waitlist.
Calgary/Banff Hiking, X-C Skiing, and Snowshoeing

I am not familiar with these groups, but let me list them here given that they have some traction.
If anyone participating or administrating these groups is willing to add a bit more background information, please reach out.
: A local hiking community for the Banff and Canmore area.
If you would like to participate to guided trips, you can hire the services of a certified mountain guide:

contents.title: Inspirational (Pictures and Ideas)
contents.description: Groups for focused on pictures and ideas

children.value:
is probably the most popular group when it comes to looking for inspiration, pictures, and practical information.
It is a bit of a monster in terms of volume of posts, and the approach is to give a little bit of everything for everyone.
If you are looking for practical information, make sure to review the main

section.
This page is dedicated to online groups providing practial information, but many other online resources exist.
The following groups are used to share practical information such as:
Recent events (bear attacks and other incidents)
also provides useful tools such as guidebooks, trip reports posted on various blogs, outdoor gear, weather, and booking information.

is probably the most popular Facebook group when it comes to looking for inspiration, pictures, and practical information.
It is a bit of a monster in terms of volume of posts, and the approach is to give a little bit of everything for everyone.
is a popular group for advanced hikers and scramblers. The moderation team is trying their best to promote best practices and knowledge.
. The Scrambling in the Canadian Rockies group is for sharing trip reports and conditions, finding partners, and seeking advice related to scrambling in the Canadian Rockies.

's purpose is to celebrate the passion for ultralight backpacking, thru hiking, and its related community. While not being a group specific to the Canadian Rockies, there is a strong presence from the region.
Kananasky Country Public Safety FB Group
Lake O'Hara Hiking and Camping Planning, Updates, and Trip Reports
: Anything and everything about Lake O'Hara in Yoho National Park, including trip reports and trail condition updates
: Among other things, provides frequent trail condition updates about Mount Temple

Facebook group to meet hikers, scramblers, and climbers through an environment
where members can connect, share experiences, and build lasting friendships.
The group caters to those with an intermediate to advanced skill level in either hiking or climbing.
The group is not dedicated to finding activity partners, but the community is tight-knit and people use the group to coordinate activities.
The group is used to post about trail conditions, scrambling routes, to find partners for avalanche and crevasse rescue courses, etc.
The group is a place where you interact with people first (share tips, ask information, etc) to build connections, and then find hiking/scrambling/climbing partners as a result of the interaction.

Be aware that hikes and scrambles posted on this group might be extremely difficult scrambles or climbs. Do your own research to ensure that you know what you are getting into and be prepared to be self-reliant in case the group you join needs to split. When in doubt, ask the event's organizer. Event organizers are not guides responsible for your safety. They are simply hiking companions who are posting their hikes.

The group isn't a structured organization. Each hike organizer has his/her own philosophy and rules, so make sure to confirm expectations when you join a hike. If you don't like the rules of the current organizers, you are more than welcome to post your own hikes with the rules you want.
: Share your hike plans here and join others on their adventures.

: Share your hike plans here and join others on their adventures. When posting, be sure to include the date, time, and location. Feel free to share photos‚Äîbut only from events listed in this group. For everything else, please use other groups.
If you're looking for hiking partners in general, but don't have specific hikes/dates in mind,
may be a better place for you to post.
How is it different than the other FB groups?
Understand how this group relates to
page to understand the similarities and differences with other meetup groups.
There are better groups to ask information about
hiking trails, conditions, trail closures, bear attacks
Note that unlike most other groups, this is a

group (the content can be accessed without joining the group). This makes it possible for instance to create and
share an
to people who are not members of the group (i.e. in other groups, private discussions, etc).
of the group are minimalistic and mostly common sense: as long as you are respectful and
The rest of this section describes the rationale for each of the rules that are in place.
We're all in this together to create a Welcoming environment. Let's treat everyone with respect. Healthy debates are natural, but kindness is required.
Why do we have this rule in place?
We want the group to be fun to interact with and leave toxicity out.
Make sure everyone feels safe. Bullying of any kind isn't allowed, and degrading comments about things like race, religion, culture, sexual orientation, gender or identity will not be tolerated.
Why do we have this rule in place?
We want the group to be fun to interact with and leave toxicity out.

Give more than you take in this group. Self-promotion, spam and irrelevant links aren't allowed. Legit links to other free groups or pages that help people organize events and find hiking friends are encouraged though.
Why do we have this rule in place?
is to provide a space to connect hikers. Please
refrain from posting any other information

Let‚Äôs keep it simple and focused: Share your hike plans here and join others on their adventures. When posting, be sure to include the date, time, and location. Feel free to share photos‚Äîbut only from events listed in this group. For everything else, please use other groups.
Why do we have this rule in place?

The reason Alberta Hikers Together has been created is because the general-purpose hiking groups often buried meetup posts under a flood of other content. The idea here is to make it easier to find hiking partners.
Posting pictures / trip reports is especially encouraged for people who post their hike plans in the group, since it helps to build excitement for upcoming trips.
are a better match for those who want to share photos of past adventures without organizing a hike.

Finally, we ask that members be specific about the date, time, and trails/hikes being planned. Not only does this make posts more actionable for others, it also helps combat spammers who tend to post vague, non-actionable requests.
If you‚Äôre looking to post general requests for hiking partners, check out
‚Äîthey‚Äôre happy to welcome those kinds of posts.
None of the trips are hosted by professional guides and all of us have average navigation skills. You assume all responsibility for your safety, well-being, and preparedness.
Why do we have this rule in place?

To remind people that nobody in the group is a professional guide. You should assume that the people you hike with have average mountain and navigation skills and you assume all responsibility for your safety, well-being and preparedness. Do your own research to ensure that you know what you are getting into and be prepared to be self-reliant in case we have to split.
If you want more structured events, check out the
that tend to have stable organizers that enforce stricter rules.
Use the public group to reach out to other members. Inappropriate messages will not be tolerated.
Why do we have this rule in place?

The group's sole purpose is to provide a space to connect hikers. Nothing else. If someone posts a hike and you want to join, feel free to reach out to them. Otherwise, consider that to be inappropriate.
No selling of items and gear. Camping and backcountry sites may be posted here for the same face value. Add markups and you will be banned.
Why do we have this rule in place?

If you have an extra camping spot that you won't use, you are welcome to post it for the same face value. It's a great way to connect with other hikers if you're only going to use one car/tent out of the two allowed on your camping site. And by extension, even if you can't make it all, you're still welcome to post it, it will make someone else's weekend!
What we want to avoid though are scalpers and scammers. Anyone doing shady deals will be banned.

Be aware that hikes and scrambles posted on this group might range from a little walk along the river to extremely difficult scrambles. Do your own research to ensure that you know what you are getting into and be prepared to be self-reliant in case the group you join needs to split. When in doubt, ask the event's organizer. Event organizers are not guides responsible for your safety. They are simply hiking companions who are posting their hikes.

The group isn't a structured organization. Each hike organizer has his/her own philosophy and rules, so make sure to confirm expectations when you join a hike. If you don't like the rules of the current organizers, you are more than welcome to post your own hikes with the rules you want.

üí° Are you a regular hike organizer? No matter what group you post in, if you‚Äôd like a little space to share your hiking vibe, rules, or trail philosophy ‚Äî we‚Äôd love to include you! Just reach out! ü•æüìù
Not all hike organizers are cut from the same trail map üó∫Ô∏è ‚Äî and that‚Äôs totally okay! Some love fast summits and no breaks, others prefer long picnics with 360¬∞ views. üçïüèîÔ∏è‚òÄÔ∏è
This section is here to give each organizer their own space to tell you what to expect when tagging along on one of their adventures. No surprises (except for the views üòç).
‚Äî Sunrise starts, summit photoshoots, and type-2 fun guaranteed! üåÑüì∏

contents.title: Sami
contents.description: What to expect when you join one of Sami's hikes

children.value: üéØ Want to join a Sami hike?
So, you‚Äôre thinking of joining a Sami hike? Woohoo! üéâ

If you‚Äôve landed on this page, chances are you followed a link from one of my hiking invites and you‚Äôre wondering:
‚ÄúWhat exactly am I signing up for here?‚Äù üë£üì®

üß† No Interviews: Unlike some organizers, I don‚Äôt run a vetting process ‚Äî no fitness tests, no gear checklists, no ‚Äúare-you-worthy-of-this-hike‚Äù quizzes üìùüôÖ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. Instead, I believe in shared responsibility and good communication ü§ùüí¨:
and trip philosophy so you can decide if it feels like a good match üíõü•æ

üîç You do your research to see if the hike fits your skills, experience, and comfort level. And if my plan seems fishy üêü or sketchy ‚ùì‚Äî call me out! I‚Äôm no expert, just a stoked hiker with a spreadsheet.

üéí You choose your own adventure gear ‚Äî food, water, maps, spikes, rainbow windbreakers ‚Äî it‚Äôs all up to you. üó∫Ô∏èü•™üíß Don't complain if you're usually good with 1L of water and you end up needing 5L on a 15-hour Summer Sami Special hike that doesn't have any source of water along the way. Or if you're cold at the summit because all you brought is a windbreaker and don't usually enjoy long breaks at the summit. Be ultralight at your own risk!
ü§î Got questions or doubts? Just message me! I‚Äôm always down to chat and sort things out.
üéØ The goal isn‚Äôt perfection. We‚Äôre just trying to avoid those rare ‚Äúoops-this-wasn‚Äôt-a-fit‚Äù moments üö´ü§ï
What to Expect on a Classic Sami Hike
section to understand what a typical Sami hike looks like.

So if you like your hikes with honesty and a sprinkle of shared accountability‚Ä¶
Welcome to the crew üèïÔ∏èü´∂
Let‚Äôs plan smart, hike happy, and enjoy the wild together! üåÑ‚ú®
ü•æ What to Expect on a Classic Sami Hike
Here‚Äôs what a typical Summer hike looks like when the sun is shining and the vibes are high:
Most of the hikes I post are scrambles with difficult terrain (scree, loose/crumbly rock).
While every hike differs, I usually plan 12-to-15-hour days when I expect bluebird skies + warm temps, and 7-10 hour days otherwise.
The technical term to describe these is sufferfest ü§≠, so don't trust the stats (distance/elevation), they don't tell the whole story! üòé
page links to useful resources to help with the planning process.
5:00am at the trailhead is the norm üò¥üåÑ ‚Äî sometimes even earlier for those extra-spicy objectives üèîÔ∏èüî•
In Spring/Fall, we sleep in (a little) ‚Äî usually around 7:00am starts, since it‚Äôs too chilly for long snack + photo breaks ‚ùÑÔ∏è
Respecting the early birds üê¶ means we start at the posted time!

Meeting time = 15 mins before the hike begins.
So if the hike starts at 5am and you roll up at 5:05‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre actually 20 minutes late. Oops! ‚è≥üòÖ
When the sun‚Äôs out and the mountains are sparkling ‚ú®, I‚Äôm on a photo frenzy. Expect lots of stops!
Hate photo breaks? Join a colder weather hike ‚Äî the colder it is, the fewer pics I take üò¨üì∑
Love being trail-famous? Wear bright colors and strike a pose ‚Äî I share all pics in full-res after! üé®üëØ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüñºÔ∏è
I say moderate‚Ä¶ but everyone defines that differently ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Boring trail? We zoom üõ£Ô∏èüí®
Epic views? We slow to a crawl for photos and oohs and ahhs üêåüì∏üåÑ
When there is a beautiful alpine lake or an inviting waterfall pool, we always take time for a cold dip! üëôü©≤
If the event is listed as ‚Äúfast,‚Äù I mean it! Otherwise, expect a mixed rhythm that adapts to the trail.

If the weather‚Äôs nice, expect to chill for hours at the top üòéüß∫
Food, naps, views, deep chats ‚Äî it‚Äôs a summit hang, not a summit sprint.
Not a fan of long breaks? You‚Äôve got options:
üëã It‚Äôs cool to split off early if you want to head down.
üßä Come on colder-season hikes ‚Äî I‚Äôm not a summit-sitter when it‚Äôs freezing!
Goal = start hiking early-enough to wrap up by 5pm without rushing, especially on Saturdays so we can:
üèïÔ∏è Still have time to chill at camp
üõå üí§ Go to bed early, to be ready for another adventure the next day!
üìÜ On Sundays (Fundays), I‚Äôm happy to finish later ‚Äî let traffic pass and ride the mellow wave home üöó
üï† If plans shift, no stress ‚Äî starting early gives us plenty of cushion to wrap up later. I like planning with extra room for detours and surprises.

Ready for adventure? Bring good vibes, bright gear, and maybe a snack to share üòÑüëüüåà
See you on the trail! üèîÔ∏èüíõ

Just a friendly heads-up: I‚Äôm not a pro mountain guide üß¢‚ùå‚õ∞Ô∏è.
I‚Äôve got average navigation skills, decent mountain sense, and a big love for adventure ‚Äî but you are 100% in charge of your own safety, prep, and decisions üß≠ü•æ
Think of me as your enthusiastic trail buddy, not your personal GPS or mountain guru ü§ì‚ú®
üìå Here‚Äôs what that means in practice:
‚ùó Don‚Äôt assume I fully know what I‚Äôm doing ‚Äî I often have plans, but Mother Nature might have other ideas ‚òÅÔ∏èü™®
üîç Do your own research ‚Äî read up, map it out, and know what you‚Äôre getting into
üó∫Ô∏è Bring your own maps and route info ‚Äî be ready in case we need to split or adjust plans
üßÉ Pack food + water like we‚Äôre doing an epic ‚Äî sunny days + long breaks = thirstier hikers üòÖ‚òÄÔ∏è
ü™ñ Bring the right gear (helmet, spikes, axe, whatever the mountain calls for). Not sure? Ask the crew!
üî¶ Plans change! Extra layers and a headlamp can go from ‚Äúnice to have‚Äù to ‚Äúthank goodness I brought this‚Äù real fast üåÑü•∂
The mountain doesn‚Äôt care how confident we sound ‚Äî so let‚Äôs all come prepared, stay humble, and have each other‚Äôs backs üíöüèïÔ∏èüß†
We‚Äôll have way more fun knowing we‚Äôve got the essentials just in case! üë£üéí
üß© Sticking Together vs. Splitting the Group

Ah yes ‚Äî the great trail debate: Should we all hike together like one big happy trail family? üë£üë®‚Äçüë©‚Äçüëß‚Äçüë¶
Or is it cool to split up if people are vibing at different paces? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüê¢

Here‚Äôs my take:
I‚Äôm 100% chill with splitting ‚Äî especially in bigger groups (7‚Äì9 folks). It‚Äôs totally normal for different hikers to settle into different paces üö∂‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è and honestly, forcing a group to move as one mega-hiker can make things feel clunky and weird.

‚ú® Live and let hike! ‚ú®
Sharing part of the trail is still sharing something special ‚Äî even if we don‚Äôt stick together the whole way üèîÔ∏èüß°
üß≠ But What If Someone Overestimated the Hike?

It happens ‚Äî we‚Äôre all human (and occasionally overconfident üòÖ).
If someone‚Äôs not feeling it, my take is: unless it‚Äôs a safety emergency, we should look for smart, kind options üí°‚ù§Ô∏è ‚Äî like having them chill at a scenic spot while the group continues.
üîÅ Loops are trickier than out-and-backs, so let‚Äôs think things through before we split.
üß† Things to Keep in Mind if We Do Split:
üêª Minimum group size rules (hello, Parks Canada bear safety!) mean splitting may not be allowed
‚Ü©Ô∏è Out-and-backs are easier to manage ‚Äî we‚Äôll be returning the same way anyway!
üó∫Ô∏è Everyone should have maps + route info ‚Äî don‚Äôt assume someone else has it!
üßó‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è How technical is the hike? A mellow walk or a spicy scramble?
üö∂‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Is the trail busy or are we totally alone in the wilderness?
üöó Carpool chaos is real ‚Äî don‚Äôt leave your ride behind without a plan üò¨

BTW ‚Äî this goes both ways! üíØ
There have been times when I didn‚Äôt feel good about pushing for a summit and waited for the group to go up and come back. It‚Äôs all about mutual respect and using common sense üßò‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüå§Ô∏è
If you‚Äôre someone who really prefers sticking together the whole time, no problem! Just let me know before the hike so we can set expectations and avoid awkward trail drama üó£Ô∏èü§ù
Bottom line: We use our brains, our hearts, and our GPS üìçüíöüó∫Ô∏è ‚Äî and try not to split the group in silly ways. Deal?
üèïÔ∏è What to Expect on a Multi-Day Camping or Hut Trip
First things first ‚Äî my fave multi-day trips are the chill, flexible, go-with-the-flow kind üòéüåÑ. That means: no pressure to do everything together. Seriously.

The best vibes happen when everyone feels free to do their own thing by day ‚Äî hike solo, chill at camp, chase peaks, nap in a meadow üí§üåº ‚Äî and then come together in the evening for laughs, shared food, and cozy campfire hangs üî•üç≤üåå.
üó∫Ô∏è Everyone‚Äôs explored different trails ‚Äî we‚Äôve all got different ‚Äúmust-dos‚Äù
üê¢üêá Pace, break style, and start time vary a lot ‚Äî mine are in the
, but I adapt depending on the weather üå¶Ô∏è
üßò‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Some folks need chill rest days; others are ready to send it daily üí™. A diverse group means you'll have company regardless.
ü§ù We don‚Äôt need to match 100% ‚Äî just be upfront about your style/preferences!
üîÑ Bad weather tends to mellow everyone out anyway (later starts, shorter hikes), so magic compatibility can happen unexpectedly ‚òÅÔ∏èüí´
‚òÄÔ∏èüåßÔ∏è How Weather & Smoke Shape My Plans:
Bluebird skies + warm temps? Count me in for 3:00am starts and long, leisurely summit hangs: 12-to-15-hour days üòçüì∏
Smoky skies? I‚Äôm out. Those are rest/snack/book/lake float days üò∑üìñüõ∂
Cloudy but dry? Let‚Äôs hit the mid-tier hikes: 7-10 hour days ‚Äî still fun, just a little less photogenic ‚òÅÔ∏è
Rainy? You‚Äôll need to be my motivational hype squad to get me up 1200m for a whiteout summit üòÇ‚õ∞Ô∏è‚òîÔ∏è
üéØ Bottom line: We don‚Äôt need to do everything together to have a great trip ‚Äî A diverse group gives more options to everyone üß°
What to Expect on a Classic Sami Hike
‚è∞ Why do your hikes start sooo early?
Ah yes, the infamous alpine start üåÑ ‚Äî while some folks are hitting snooze, I‚Äôm already tying my boots in the dark üò¥ü•æ
Here‚Äôs the deal: different hikers have different priorities. Mine? I like to squeeze the juice out of every hiking day üçãüë£
üì∏ Plenty of photo breaks ‚Äî yes, we‚Äôre hiking, but also yes, you will be asked to pose on a rock like a majestic mountain goat üêê‚ú®
üèîÔ∏è Long summit hangs ‚Äî think hours at the top, soaking in views, sunshine, snacks, and trail tea üßÉ‚òÄÔ∏èüßÄ
üçª Early finish (~5pm) ‚Äî so we can celebrate with a cold dip üèä‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è and a cold beer üç∫ (or both!), followed by real food and early zzz‚Äôs üò¥
üõ†Ô∏è Wiggle room for chaos ‚Äî because let‚Äôs be real: plans are great until the trail says ‚Äúplot twist!‚Äù ü§™‚õ∞Ô∏è

To make all that magic happen, we start early. Like, really early.
Real-life examples:
üåÖ Pharaoh Peak: started at 4am, caught sunrise at Healy Pass üåÑ (August 2022)
üèûÔ∏è Skyline Trail: started at 5am, because Jasper sun waits for no one üòé (September 2023)
Oh ‚Äî and just so you know, both of those were listed as ‚ÄúFAST‚Äù hikes üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüí®, not your average leisurely strolls. Pace yourself accordingly!
üïí Why don‚Äôt you wait for people who are late?

Great question! When I post a hike, the meeting time is actually 15 minutes before we hit the trail ü•æ‚è≥ ‚Äî that buffer is built in for bathroom breaks üöª, gear tweaks üéí, and tying those stubborn boot laces üëü.
So if we start hiking ‚Äúon time,‚Äù we‚Äôve actually already waited 15 minutes ‚åõ ‚Äî which feels like a fair grace period, right?
Is 15 minutes a fair wait? I think so! ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
If not‚Ä¶ what is? ü§î Should we bring a stopwatch and take votes? üòÑ
Here‚Äôs why I stick to this system:
üì∂ Many trailheads have no cell service, so waiting around for a text that never comes just doesn‚Äôt work.
üßä Early mornings can be chilly, and it‚Äôs not fair to leave the punctual folks shivering while we wait.
‚úÖ It keeps things simple, consistent, and respectful of everyone‚Äôs time ‚Äî especially at 4am when we‚Äôre all half-asleep anyway üò¥‚òïÔ∏è
Bottom line: I love hiking with people‚Ä¶ but I also love starting on time. If you‚Äôre ever unsure, message me ahead of time or aim to arrive a little early üòã
üì£ Where do you post your hikes?
I usually kick things off by creating an event on
üèûÔ∏è ‚Äî it‚Äôs a public group, so anyone can see and join the fun! üéâüëÄ
Then I share it with a few other awesome trail-loving communities:
‚Äì a private group full of friendly folks looking to hit the trails.
‚Äì for the mountain goats and rock scramblers among us üêêüßó‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
Also! There‚Äôs a whole section on
if you‚Äôre curious about more ways to connect and hike with others üìÖüë£üí¨
ü§î Why don‚Äôt you ‚Äúvet‚Äù people like other organizers do?
I don‚Äôt really see myself as a capital-O Organizer üôÖ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüìã ‚Äî I‚Äôm just someone who loves hiking and enjoys sharing the trail with cool humans ü•æ‚ù§Ô∏è

Some organizers go full interview-mode before each hike‚Ä¶ and honestly, that sounds like a lot of admin for my dirtbag lifestyle üòÖ‚õ∫Ô∏è. I‚Äôd rather spend that time chasing peaks than reading bios.
So far, my track record is: one ‚Äúoops‚Äù moment per summer (May‚ÄìNov) ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è ‚Äî nothing catastrophic, just the kind of thing you laugh about after snacks and rehydration üßÉüç´
Plus, a few of those oopsies were kinda on me ‚Äî setting better expectations is something I‚Äôm working on üëÄüìù
And even if I wanted to vet folks‚Ä¶ how good would I be at it? I‚Äôm still pretty new to Alberta üê£‚õ∞Ô∏è and learning this whole mountain game one trail at a time.
Honestly? Most of the people I hike with are way more experienced and better prepared than me üß†üìö. Sometimes I feel like I‚Äôm tagging along on their hike!
So yeah ‚Äî no gatekeeping here. Just vibes, transparency, and good-faith effort. Let‚Äôs hike, learn, and laugh it off together üí¨üë£üî•
ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I want to join a hike but can‚Äôt commit just yet‚Ä¶
No worries at all ‚Äî I‚Äôm super chill about it! üòé If you can make it, awesome! If not, no hard feelings ‚Äî catch you on the next adventure! üëãü•æ

Just a tiny favor: if you‚Äôre a maybe, please give me a heads-up üôã‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è and try not to lock in any carpool plans üöóüö´ that could throw a wrench in everyone else‚Äôs groove. Sharing is caring, after all! üíñ‚ú®
I‚Äôm usually out camping under the stars üåå on Friday and Saturday nights from late June through early September ‚Äî so carpooling on those weekends isn‚Äôt in the cards for me. üèïÔ∏è‚ú®
But when we‚Äôre heading back from Calgary, I usually rally the troops to meet up and carpool from the trusty old
‚õΩÔ∏èüöô. Perfect spot to fuel up and hit the road together!

Plus ‚Äî every hike gets its own group chat üì±üí¨, so talk to you in there to find your carpool crew, share rides, or even trade snacks for the trip. ü•®üç´ Let‚Äôs make the ride as fun as the hike!
ü§î What‚Äôs the usual crew size on your hikes?

Most of my adventures roll with a cozy crew of 3-4 awesome humans üë´ü•æ‚Äî just the right vibe for good chats and laughs üòÑ.
Every now and then, we get a bigger party going ‚Äî think 7-8 trailblazers strong! üéâüë£ More fun, more stories, more pictures üì∏ !
ü§î Why do you post your hikes so late in the week?
Great question! Here‚Äôs the deal: I‚Äôm in a committed relationship with good weather üòé‚òÄÔ∏è ‚Äî and I don‚Äôt like getting ghosted by last-minute snowstorms ‚ùÑÔ∏è or surprise smoke üò∑üî•.

The more unpredictable the conditions (hello, Alberta!), the longer I wait to lock in the plan. I like to save the big, epic hikes üèîÔ∏èüí™ for those perfect bluebird days üåà, and swap in more chill or flexible options when the forecast plays hard to get.

So yeah‚Ä¶ sometimes a Saturday hike doesn‚Äôt show up until Thursday night or even Friday afternoon üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüì≤. If you‚Äôre curious what‚Äôs cooking before I post, just shoot me a message ‚Äî happy to give you a sneak peek üëÄüëüüéí
üìù Do you keep a log of your hikes?

You bet I do! ü§ìü•æ
Welcome to my treasure trove of trails ‚Äî check out

üìä‚ú®
It‚Äôs packed with all the goodies: hike dates üìÖ, peak names üèîÔ∏è, stats üìà, and links to my Garmin adventures ‚åöÔ∏èüí•

The Garmin portal doesn‚Äôt show GPS tracks directly (rude, I know üò§), but if you want GPX files üß≠ or route info üó∫Ô∏è, just give me a shout! I‚Äôm always happy to share the trail love üíåüå≤
üò∑ Do you hike when it's smoky?

Not really my vibe ‚Äî I like my lungs the way they are! üí®ü´Å
If the smoke rolls in and the forecast takes a turn, I‚Äôll usually cancel the hike or scramble.
That said, if you‚Äôre feeling brave and still want to go full mountain goat without me, go for it! I‚Äôll be cheering you on from somewhere with cleaner air (and probably snacks).
What to expect when joining a multi-day camping or hut trip
‚Äî it‚Äôs full of helpful info and a few spicy surprises. üå∂Ô∏è

If you‚Äôre a planner, hit me up in üìÖ November or December ‚Äî that‚Äôs when I start scheming and dreaming up üåû summer adventures. (Most of the national park bookings go live in January ‚Äî it‚Äôs a race, and we‚Äôre in it to win it.)
If you‚Äôre more of a last-minute butterfly ü¶ã, no worries ‚Äî keep an eye on

. Sometimes magic happens: someone cancels, and üí• boom!
There‚Äôs space for you to join the fun.
ü•æ What is a Summer Sami Special‚Ñ¢?
You‚Äôll know it‚Äôs a Summer Sami Special‚Ñ¢ when the magic recipe comes together just right:
üåû Weather: That dreamy summer sweet sun, bluebird skies, and zero wildfire smoke in the air. Yes please.
üèîÔ∏è The Big Objective: A deliciously ridiculous goal ‚Äî jaw-dropping views and a Type 2 fun sufferfest that leaves everyone's legs and soul equally wrecked (in the best way).
üéâ The Vibe: An amazing crew that turns a hike into a rolling party ‚Äî full of laughs, deep chats, trail fun, and unforgettable memories.
‚è∞ Alpine Start O‚ÄôClock: If it‚Äôs not before 4am, is it even a real Sami hike? Nope.
üì∏ Photoshoots Galore: We‚Äôre talking model behavior here ‚Äî goofy poses, epic action shots, candid trail joy, and more camera clicks than summit steps.
üçª Post-Hike Joy: Done early enough to celebrate ‚Äî cold drinks, lakeside dips, shared snacks, and stories flowing around a picnic table or campsite fire.

I don‚Äôt get to pick the weather (unfortunately), but when the skies look good, I‚Äôll bring the big mountain goals ‚Äî and yes, that means a very early start. The rest ‚Äî the crew, the fun, the magic ‚Äî that‚Äôs all you. ü§ù Deal?
üóìÔ∏è Can you provide the template that you use to create FB events?

  ‚Ä¢ üòé 1h+ summit chill‚Äîwind gods permitting üå™Ô∏èü§û
  ‚Ä¢ üéØ Aim to return early/mid afternoon (potential risk of thunderstorm), then off to chill mode üòå

  ‚Ä¢ üèä Cold dip -- bring a swimming suit ü©≥üëô
  ‚Ä¢ üìµ We‚Äôll lose cell service Friday afternoon ‚Äî let‚Äôs coordinate before, or just meet at the trailhead
  ‚Ä¢ üì≤ Message me if you‚Äôre interested and I‚Äôll add you to the private chat group üîíüë•

‚ö†Ô∏è Quick Safety Note

I‚Äôm not a pro guide ‚Äî just a stoked hiker with average mountain + nav skills üß≠üòÑ
You are fully responsible for your safety, prep, and gear. Please:
  ‚Ä¢ Do your own research üß†
  ‚Ä¢ Bring proper gear üéí
  ‚Ä¢ Be self-reliant if the group splits üßç‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüßç‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

children.value: Get inspired and start planning your next adventure with these:
Trip Reports, Blogs, and GPS Traces
Don‚Äôt get caught off guard! Use these to check what Mother Nature‚Äôs cooking:
‚Äî See it with your own eyes!
‚Äî your go-to spots for updates on trail conditions, closures, sneaky detours, and all the ‚Äúshould I still go?‚Äù stuff ü•æüößüå≤
Because having the right gear makes the hike way more fun (and less cold/soggy):
To start your journey in the Canadian Rockies:
Don't Waste Your Time in the Canadian Rockies

: Their selection of hikes is an amazing starting point in the Canadian Rockies.
The book only covers the national parks (Banff, Jasper, Kootenay, Yoho and Waterton Lakes national parks, plus Mt. Robson and Mt. Assiniboine provincial parks), not the Kananaskis / Canmore region.
The two popular scrambling references used by the local community are:
Scrambles in the Canadian Rockies (Alan Kane)
: Covers Waterton, Crowsnest, Kananaskis, Canmore, Banff, Yoho, Kootenay, and Jasper
More Scrambles in the Canadian Rockies (Andrew Nugara)
: Comprehensively covers Waterton, The Castle, and Kananaskis. Also includes scrambles in Crowsnest, Banff, Highway 93 North, and Yoho.
For those interested in scrambling in Montana Glacier National Park, just south of the border:
Climb Glacier National Park, Blake Passmore
A Climber's Guide to Glacier National Park,  J. Gordon Edwards
Snowshoeing in the Canadian Rockies (Andrew Nugara)
Trip Reports, Blogs, and GPS Traces
A number of individuals in the community share their spreadsheets, trip reports, YouTube videos, GPS Traces, etc.
Annie Steve Climbing The Rockies YouTube Trip Reports
Additionally, GPX traces can be found on:
: Covers peaks in the Alberta Rockies, but also Montana Glacier National Park Rockies and much more!

links.text: Trip Reports, Blogs, and GPS Traces

children.value: If someone reading this has in-depth knowledge of all these apps and the key differences / differentiating factors, please do not hesitate to contribute improvements to this section.
: A subscription-based app providing offline maps, layers, ability to import GPX files, etc.
is an alternative worth checking out.
advertise themselves as the best FATMAP replacement (no longer available after the Strava acquisition).
Curated and community-generated trails and traces:
: The paid plans support offline use.
The following apps help figure out which peaks one is looking at. Really handy for route finding, orienteering, and satisfying your curiosity!
. The editors of Peakvisor provide a

links.text: Curated and community-generated trails and traces:

children.value: : Displays active fires and smoke on a map.
provides a smoke layer that can be activated by using the "PM2.5" layer.
NASA Fire Information for Resource Management System
: The official Alberta Wildfire Status Dashboard .
: The official British Columbia Wildfire Status Dashboard.
Direct Access to air quality forecasts
: A map allowing to visualize the current fire bans in Alberta (Cities, Provincial Parks, and National Parks)
: The current fire bans and restrictions in Alberta provincial parks.
British Columbia Fire Bans and Restrictions
: The current fire bans and restrictions in British Columbia provincial parks.

children.text: Direct Access to air quality forecasts

children.value: The Best Weather Apps for Hiking
that provides an introduction to some of these weather apps:
: Spot weather forecasting tool allowing to compare the forecasts of different models for arbitrary GPS locations (Spot = a point or specific location, Wx = short for weather).
: A forecasting tool allowing to check the forecast for a number of mountains.
: A powerful and versatile forecasting tool that provides many different layers (Wind, Smoke, Webcams, etc) and that allows visualization directly on a map.
: Similarly to Spotwx, allows to compare the forecasts of different models.
: Up-to-date satellite images that are useful to visualize the amount of snow in the mountains
: The official weather website of the Norwegian government. Uses open-source weather data from a variety of sources outside of Norway.
A number of resources are available to get more information on the trail conditions (snow, mud) and closures (grizzly bears, etc).

For those new to the area, keep in mind that because of the accumulation of snow, most of the bigger hikes/objectives in the national parks
are only dry (read: accessible) from July 15th to September 15th.

Given that the weather is highly heterogeneous in the Rockies, it is often possible to find objectives that are dry before and after this period,
but these are usually in Kananaskis. You can narrow your search to: Exshaw area, Highway 40 north of Peter Lougheed, and West Bragg Creek.
Waterton Lakes National Park Trail Conditions
Mount Revelstoke National Park Trail Conditions
People often post trail conditions and trip reports in various
has a comment section for each hike where people usually describe the trail conditions.
: Weekly heads up on sales and discounts on outdoor gear from Canadian retailers.
: Gives access to discounts on popular outdoor gear brands for
FB group is full of people promoting and selling second-hand ultralight gear.
is extremely popular among the Canadian Rockies ultralight community. The gear is
designed in the heart of the Rockies
builds the backcountry radio that most of the community seems to swear by.
members get a 20% discount on Rocky Talkies.
in November or December for the next summer. The reservations launch on different dates for each park, but are usually spread between January 15th and February 15th

. They have a rolling-window system where reservations can be made 6 months in advance for ACC members, and 3 months in advance for non-ACC members.
